byline.contributor: Jesse Coburn and Alison Smale contributed reporting from Berlin.

abstract: Oskar Groning, 94-year-old former SS soldier, admits complicity in Holocaust during Hamburg court trial, but disappoints survivors when he does not apologize to victims or their families for his actions and even tries to explain his deeds as simple obedience; ex-Nazi faces accessory to 300,000 counts of murder and could receive up to 15 years in prison if convicted.
lead_paragraph: Oskar Gröning, 94, said he could “only ask forgiveness from the Lord” at his trial over his role at the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp.

headline.main: Ex-Nazi on Trial in Germany Admits Complicity
headline.print_headline: Ex-Nazi Admits Complicity but Offers No Apology

snippet: Oskar Gröning, 94, said he could “only ask forgiveness from the Lord” at his trial over his role at the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp.

keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
keywords.name: subject
